name: Kepler-197
scenarioDescription:
The Kepler-197 Exoplanetary System

Kepler-197 is a star with 1.1539999999999997 times the mass of the Sun, and 1.12 times its radius. It is located 1088.55 light years away from the solar system.

Kepler-197 is known to have 4 exoplanets in orbit around it.

Kepler-197 b

Kepler-197 b was discovered by the Kepler observatory using the transit method. Its discovery was announced in 2014-03. Its semi-major axis is 0.06 astronomical units, as compared to Earth's which is 1 astronomical unit. It takes 5.60 Earth days to complete an orbit around its host star, Kepler-197.

The mass of Kepler-197 b is 1.01 times the mass of Earth. The radius of Kepler-197 b is 1.02 that of Earth. At less than 1.5 Earth masses, Kepler-197 b is a regular terrestrial planet, much like the terrestrial planets we find in our solar system, namely Mercury, Venus, Earth and Mars.

Kepler-197 c

Kepler-197 c was discovered by the Kepler observatory using the transit method. Its discovery was announced in 2014-03. Its semi-major axis is 0.09 astronomical units, as compared to Earth's which is 1 astronomical unit. It takes 10.35 Earth days to complete an orbit around its host star, Kepler-197.

The mass of Kepler-197 c is 1.59 times the mass of Earth. The radius of Kepler-197 c is 1.23 that of Earth. At 1.59 Earth masses, Kepler-197 c is a so called Super Earth. Super Earths could be terrestrial worlds like Earth, but they could also be ocean worlds or terrestrial worlds wrapped in a substantial atmosphere, in which case some refer to them as Mini Neptunes. No Super Earths are known to exist in our solar system, but if it exists, the so-called Planet Nine could very well be a super Earth, as it is hypothesized to have a mass between five and ten Earth masses.

Kepler-197 d

Kepler-197 d was discovered by the Kepler observatory using the transit method. Its discovery was announced in 2014-03. Its semi-major axis is 0.12 astronomical units, as compared to Earth's which is 1 astronomical unit. It takes 15.68 Earth days to complete an orbit around its host star, Kepler-197.

The mass of Kepler-197 d is 1.56 times the mass of Earth. The radius of Kepler-197 d is 1.22 that of Earth. At 1.56 Earth masses, Kepler-197 d is a so called Super Earth. Super Earths could be terrestrial worlds like Earth, but they could also be ocean worlds or terrestrial worlds wrapped in a substantial atmosphere, in which case some refer to them as Mini Neptunes. No Super Earths are known to exist in our solar system, but if it exists, the so-called Planet Nine could very well be a super Earth, as it is hypothesized to have a mass between five and ten Earth masses.

Kepler-197 e

Kepler-197 e was discovered by the Kepler observatory using the transit method. Its discovery was announced in 2014-03. Its semi-major axis is 0.16 astronomical units, as compared to Earth's which is 1 astronomical unit. It takes 25.21 Earth days to complete an orbit around its host star, Kepler-197.

The mass of Kepler-197 e is 0.76 times the mass of Earth. The radius of Kepler-197 e is 0.91 that of Earth. At less than 1.5 Earth masses, Kepler-197 e is a regular terrestrial planet, much like the terrestrial planets we find in our solar system, namely Mercury, Venus, Earth and Mars.
description: 3D visualisation and gravity simulation of the exoplanet system Kepler-197, which contains 4 planets and was discovered by Kepler.
